To thee, who mindful of the Poet's fame,</br>Dost in these lines his vagaries peruse,</br>Hast curiosity to ask his name,</br>And taste and feeling to respect his muse,—
A dark eyed lass in Common-street may say,</br>"Often we see him, and to-morrow shall,</br>Brushing, with rapid step, the leaves away,</br>To meet Miss H— walking in the mall.
There in the front of yonder garden gates,</br>Whistling "Love wakes and weeps," with solemn eye,</br>And monumental patience, oft he waits,</br>And pores upon the Belles that babble by.
For who, to cold indifference a prey,</br>Visions like these without a sigh resign'd,</br>Or passed such lovely specimens of clay,</br>Nor cast one LONGING lingering look behind?

Some Lavalette in yonder pretty lass,</br>May be concealed — who may as faithful prove;</br>Some mute and songless Sappho there may pass,</br>Some Cleopatra, chaste, yet ALL for love.</br>CETERA DESUNT.</br>
